5-tw2MypCalU0P2v9JLwBg.text: This place is soooo over rated, especially if you are Indian and know great Indian cuisine. I initially thought they would have a fresh take on Indian food, perhaps incorporating some fusion dishes. We had the tasting menu. The first few dishes were a traditional papadam and chaat. Nothing special. Just brought out in fancy tiny dishes. The tandoori fish tasted like they slapped some Shaan masala on a small piece of fish. The rice was undercooked and the prawn curry was inedible! I am shocked as to why this place has the reviews it does. Again it's all about presentation with this place and no substance!! The overpriced menu is NOT worth it! Go get some real Indian food from a hole in the wall.

eORTPiLzYXvpZaoB3A_2ww.text: An Indian restaurant with a Michelin star - enough said. Indian restaurants rarely are graced with such honors (unclear why given how amazing and diverse the cuisine is). One step into this establishment and you immediately know why this is one of the few that has managed to snag such a recognition.The decor harkens back to yesteryears that it almost feels like a time warp as you enter through the nondescript doors. While the door may be nondescript, the food is not. To take traditional Indian cuisine from different parts of India, give it a twist - yet pay homage to the original flavors, is mindbogglingly hard to do; Gymkhana exceeds where others may have and will possibly fail. The Aloo Tiki reminds you that it is just like all the other street stall tikis you may get in India, but elevated to a level of sophistication that is more appropriate in this "high society" setting. The Dosa which comes from a completely different part of India is just as delicious and again maintains its authenticity while still been given a twist to make it into something unique. The same goes for the samosas, the gol guppas (which should be ordered just for how fun they are to eat), and the mango lassis. Lastly, don't even think about skipping dessert in this place...if your wallet can manage - order one of everything and eat to your heart's content. This Indian restaurant is a must for me whenever I am in London. PS - Mindy Kaling also seems to be a fan of this place, so you know it is legit! :)

cnypPcwXXjTTitL5zZMPew.text: Delicious and lovely all around!A colleague and I were in London on a business trip and popped out to Green Park for a drink at the Wolseley. We just wandered up the road seeking a bite somewhere and stumbled into Gymkhana. The hostess was sweet though we didn't have a reservation getting use seated immediately.The staff provided helpful advice on the menu - I can truly recommend the paneer stack as well as the butter chicken masala - delish!We didn't realize it was a Michelin star restaurant till about halfway through the meal when our friendly neighbor table chatted us up.Great 'pink' G&T and desserts that looked amazing though we were too satiated to try them:)Definitely recommended!

VvpjLbhS4-_JslKnK2foyQ.text: Had a nice lunch at Gymkhana yesterday...Ambiance is nice...nothing especially unique but it's not super noisy or crowded, which is great.Service is very friendly and food came out relatively fast.Food itself is pretty good for the most part. Our party of 4 ordered a bunch of different things including naan, goat biryani, daal, bindhi, plain rice, two chicken dishes, and kachumber. I only had the daal, rice, and kachumber, which were nothing special but pretty good.A couple of negatives: the restaurant was out of shrimp and gol guppa, which I found odd. Additionally, there was a charge for the papadums, which is typically free at just about every Indian restaurant.Lunch was good but I won't be rushing to return here.

XSYX3TFLbQ1KpP7wv41nxA.text: One of the best Indian meals I can remember having. We had been wanting to come here for a while, given the hype around this being the best Indian food in a city full of great Indian places, and it lived up to those big expectations. We got a bread basket, the tandoori masala lamb chops, wild muntjac biryani, tiger prawn kebab, and dal maharani. We were blown away by the lamb chops, loved the biryani and the dal, and really liked the kebab. This was a lot of food, so while there were plenty of other things on the menu I'd like to try as well, they'll have to wait until another visit (the kid goat, quail seekh kebab, dosas, chicken butter masala, lamb shank -- too many to name, really).I also got a mango lassi to drink, which I actually wasn't that crazy about.Overall, a fantastic meal. Dishoom had always been our favorite Indian place in London (or anywhere...) and I think this surpassed it in terms of pure food quality. (Dishoom is roughly half the price though, so there's obviously a tradeoff there.)

OQKBmdZntMRDGPViUOp3wQ.text: Mixed emotions about my Monday lunch in July - first I was disappointed that the website's "business lunch" (only available Monday and Tuesday) wasn't on offer, but later I was disappointed that I'd succeeded in getting it: I thought the portion size would be suitable for my pre-teens, but the Biryani dish that was the main course of that menu was the spiciest thing the table, so basically I had punished my kids without knowing it.My wife and I couldn't choose between the 4- and 5-course lunch, so we went with the 5 and also found ourselves a little overwhelmed (next time I'd go with the 4-course for 32.50GBP, or even the 3-course one for 30GBP).  Everything was very good but nothing mind-blowing.  The potato chat that we began with (top left of my 6-panel picture) was actually one of the best-executed dishes.The bathrooms were surprising for a restaurant with a Michelin Star: not only no privacy between urinals, but also none from the outer door, which could give someone making a wrong turn quite a surprise.

photos.caption: Photo of Gymkhana - London, United Kingdom. Kid goat methi keema was most interesting dish (you mix and make your own sliders)

Photo of Gymkhana - London, United Kingdom. The Monday/Tuesday "business lunch" has no choice for the main (a biryani), and it was too spicy!

bh9U2K0sshoWN37ml6UjaQ.text: Everyone says you must have Indian food in London. I stopped here after a long day of touring London sites. Service is impeccable. I was dining alone so got a weird single table but no matter, I came here to try London Indian food. First off, I don't know much about Indian food. I eat 3 dishes usually. Tikka masala, butter chicken, and Korma.  Yikes the menu had stuff that wasn't familiar. But they did have butter chicken. The waiter recommended a starter. A goat dish, their speciality. Kid goat methi keema, Saudi, pao. It was a bit spicy, but I'm kinda wimpy. Waiter was nice and offered yogurt. The butter chicken was delicious. Creamy. Tomatoey. A bit spicy. The chicken is dark meat. One piece had s bit of gristle but otherwise delish. Overall service was wonderful. Food delicious. If you're in the area do visit. It's 10:30pm and the place is still packed.

BgSk5vjHN2S8h7UJsoLudg.text: We stopped by for their £25 or £30 lunch special and shared our meals family-style. Needless to say, I WILL be returning someday. The food was incredibly flavorful and spicy, plus the customer service was incredible; one of the servers invited us to his family's home in Jaipur. Great drinks, too. 11/10 experience.

rdRPqsQIirP4KfQDT01nnA.text: Great service and nice decor. As for the food I can't say that it was spectacular or tasted better than I've had before. They do however have a wide drink menu.My friend ordered the vegetarian tasting menu and I ordered the meat version. Overall very filling, as well as wide selection of dishes. I've never had brain before, but I had it here.. not bad. We also noticed the dishes were overly salty, but then again if you like salty dishes than this might be your place.

asNSaKJ997zAUzuYlWYRxw.text: Gymkhana is AMAZING! We didn't have a reservation got a seat in the bar...possibly the coziest, most charming booth in the whole place! The bar was in the basement of the establishment. Both floors were full of such elegance...that of which you would expect at a gentleman's club. The drink menu was extensive.The cuisine at Gymkhana is impressive! We decided that we would go on the servers recommendations for dinner. She did a great job directing us to dishes we thoroughly enjoyed and had perfect quantities for the four of us as we ate family style! The ingredients were fresh and delicious...the chutneys giving just the right balance to each bite of food! Gymkhana was awarded a Michelin Star in 2014 and I see why. Both the quality and creativity in the food and it's presentation were impeccable. Our evening was well spent enjoying each other, good food and great ambience!

Fk-AhSCFaZwerPV2u3n0Yg.text: Our reservations were for 6 pm on a weekday and our table was ready when we walked in. The decor was relatively traditional and fancy while not being too overbearing. The entire waitstaff was phenomenal throughout our entire meal and helpful with the menu. We ordered the goat appetizer, duck appetizer, and also the biryani. Every dish was perfect and had soooo much flavor! I would definitely check this place out again as the food was delicious and reasonably priced.

abtFy0hQuClypxVqZzXPbw.text: Gymkhana is modeled (and named) after social and sporting clubs in the days of the Raj. As such, the vibe here is both unique and interesting. More "casual bistro" than "Michelin-starred restaurant". What makes Gymkhana stand out even more is the creativity with their dishes, several of which incorporate a modern twist to classic Indian preparations. Don't leave without trying their kid goat keema and wild muntjac biryani. The lamb chops were also some of the best I've ever had, although quite pricey.

bzYdVTxC-W2a75_-W9rG1g.text: Date of Visit: 07.05.18Time: 14.25Review: Always great service great and menus always explained really well. We had on Vegetarian sample menu and mixture of other dishes and you can share, this is the best bet as you get a lot of food and having the variety is great. The food options and flavours are second to none and not a fusion place but indian food done well with care and attention to the detail in the flavour. I do not mention the drinks but they do a wide selection including a good selection of Mocktails.  Dress Code: Everyone was smart or smart casual but I don't think they have any restrictions Booking Process: Very easy to book on the phoneLocation: 42 Albermarle Street, London, W1S 4JHCuisine Type: IndianDecor & Lighting: Always dim lit. It is nice but nothing too special. Heating and Cooling: The resturant has AC but not overlay cold. And got out but nice inside. Not too hot and not too cold. DB Level: 78.6Db, it was easy to talk and even though all tables occupied we could still have a nice conversationWe had the following: Papad : A good selection of different types of papad with a nice mango chutney and also a great chutney with prawns but nothing to spicy. All home made the way it should be. Aloo Tikki chat : Full of flavour and a good size portion to share. Traditional flavour as you would expect.  This was part of the Vegetarian sampling menu. Planner tikka on a Sweet corn chat : Again good portion to share and a nice traditional taste with twist of sweet corn. Also the middle layer had a distinct but complimentary taste which really sets this aside from a good Indian resturant to a great indian resturant. This was part of the Vegetarian sampling menuDosa : Another great traditional tasting and full of flavour and with another little twist in the tomato sauce which I also enjoyed. Which is like a reduced thickened Dal as you normally but a great compliment. This was part of the Vegetarian sampling menuChicken tikka : Really succulent and good size portion, perfectly cooked with a nice spicy marinade that just kicks in a few moments later. Comes with a great beetroot raita that helps cool everything down. This again shows the subtle differences that make a difference on your pallet which all just work together. Channa Bhatura : Traditional but not oily as many others. This was part of the Vegetarian sampling menuBlack lentil : Traditional taste but something at least you know what you will get each and every time. This was part of the Vegetarian sampling menuAubergine : Normally I hate aubergine but this is special and I fully recommend you try this dish. This was part of the Vegetarian sampling menuMuntjac Biriyani with rose petal raita : The Top pastry is cut off by the server and put to the side. Great portion size. A Crispy pastry so you get it all from pastry to rice and meat so a whole meal in one. Sweet tasting rice and deer cooked well and taste more like light lamb and not gamey at all. Raita : There was a special hint of sweetness and tang but perfect blend to go with the Biriyani and makes the dish completely different. This was part of the Vegetarian sampling menuBill / Cost: £160.88 for threeConclusion: A great classic resturant with some great flavours and excellent service. We have been before and each time we leave with a smile and full belly! If you want something traditional which can cater for vegetarians as well and has a few twists this is the place to go.

pYoknRd-8KQ2G6whO8fNkQ.text: Very good innovative Indian food. Definitely not your typical Indian restaurant. They take normal food and puts a spin on it. Drinks are also tasty. Food portions are a lot smaller than most Indian restaurants in the States. We got the following: - kid goat- duck dosas - fish tikka - lamb chops - pork cheek vindaloo- wasn't too spicy - butter chicken - side of greensService could be better. Took 10 minutes for the waiter to come to our table.

JOD7EK4HfVyDFskNTOYvGg.text: (4.5 stars) The restaurant is beautiful, the food here is wonderful and the lunch menu (£25 for an appetizer and main entree) is a great option. The food can be a bit spicy if you're not used to spicy foods, otherwise you should be fine. Overall the main entrees are really the stars. The papadum to start is light, crispy, and diverse with two nice chutneys. The appetizers are very enjoyable but not outstanding, still though I would recommend the potato chat. Of the main entrees, the hariyali bream is fantastic, the tandoori chicken pretty much slid off the bone (and had a wonderful sauce with it), and the kid goat was complex and super tasty. Truly can't go wrong with any of them!

photos.caption: Photo of Gymkhana - London, United Kingdom. Hariyali Bream

yC8xyUBSej7aheZpCzo0yA.text: My friend's favorite Indian restaurant in London is Gymkhana so I'd been meaning to check it out for a while. The boo and I decided to do the four course dinner last Saturday in between Harry Potter play acts (!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!). Dinner opens at 5:30 PM and we figured we would be a little rushed for time so we got there before it opened. We were immediately seated at 5:30 PM. They were full of reservations (luckily, the bar has a full menu and is walk-in) but since we were early, the hostess said she could seat us at a table if we left by 7:30 PM.We started off by ordering Mango Lassis. They were excellent, and came in handy since some of the food was spicy and yogurt is the perfect way to calm your tongue. Then we had one of each things on the four course menu (four courses for £35 per person from 5:30-6:00 PM. With service fees, I think it comes out closer to £50 per person). We had the:Prawn chips and chutney to start. Yum yum!Potato Chat: delicious and the portion size was huge! Loved the slightly sweet yet spicy flavoring and the chickpeas were spot on.Hariyali Bream: a lighter, delicate dish. Liked the simple flavoring and mildness of the fish.Tandoori Gobhi: spicy cauliflower! It wasn't too spicy, but I was glad I had the Mango Lassi. The cauliflower was a little overly grilled for me.Chicken Butter Masala: oh my gosh, is this what butter chicken is actually supposed to take like?!? It had this amazing smoked flavor and the sauce wasn't too creamy or heavy. So amazing! I think we both wish we had ordered two of these.Saag Paneer: similar to the chicken, the paneer was way lighter than the paneer I've had in the States. It featured nice mild flavors and some big chunks of paneer. We enjoyed it, but if we were to go back, we'd probably get two chickens. The mains also came with Dal (amazing lentils), Aloo Methi Mattar (mild potatoes that were great as a side), rice, and naan (believe these were of the whole wheat variety).Mango Kheer: we were both super full and couldn't even finish the mango rice pudding-like dessert. It was nice to get a fruity flavor after all the potatoes.Ras Malai: loved this! If I could just drink the liquid normally I totally would. It was especially good with the little cookie they gave us with our check.The service here was excellent, and they do a great job of pacing out the food based on how fast you eat so we were able to make it back to the theater with time to spare. We were both so full for the rest of the night. Would definitely come back, especially for more of that chicken.

4epLF3YkoBsx_45kTnSAVg.text: Enjoyed the atmosphere and the food. With all the hype, it didn't blow our minds, but it was good.

S-FYr8EHDO9dRp16jADGSw.text: Walked in at 8 PM on a weekday and somehow was able to get a seat for one immediately without a reservation. I ordered the pork cheek vindaloo with naan on the side. There were three types of naan: plain, garlic, and mint. The vindaloo was quite enjoyable, but to me it just tasted like a good curry, definitely one of the better ones I've had, but with nothing really innovative or mind-blowing that would justify the price. The level of spiciness was just about right.3.5 stars

09Y9r7fpAH9gaE1XTQT1SQ.text: Went to Gymkhana this past week and had 3-plate tasting menu for lunch. Was great food and amazing service - best I've ever had at Indian restaurant! Started with duck dosa and goat keema - both are must haves. We will definitely be back!

Yifw3HQQnBFm3iiN9v4TxA.text: My wife is Indian and we were married in India and her mom cooks for us frequently, so we know good Indian food when we have it. Gymkhana? WOW. We have the 5 course meal and EVERY DISH was fantastic. The meat was perfect, the spice level was there but not dangerous, and the service was attentive. Even the drink menu was awesome with aptly named drinks. The crème brulee was special because it had gulab jamun in it, very nice treat. Super convenient to the theaters as well, easy to find off several tube lines. Do yourself a favor and go if you're craving more-than-authentic Indian food.

f2COE55COr3eLdN8gmrSNw.text: Underwhelming. Go to Dishoom! It's not worth the money. You can go to other Indian restaurants in London that are much better in terms of flavor.

UxE8HxHxnJiBQgh8S2lgkA.text: This has got to be my most favorite restaurant in the world.  I am not exaggerating.  I am a heavy business traveller and I eat at a lot of good restaurants.  This one is off the charts with the quality of food and amazing service.  I always come here last minute and end up sitting at the bar downstairs.  Love it.

YJl8YpB1KPDBm59U3TMI7Q.text: Recommend the Tandoori Broccoli and Beet Kebabs here - This is the first-ever Indian restaurant to be named England's Restaurant of the Year - nationalrestaurantawards…

ndlN7774YQkKP_C4SCcuow.text: This place was recommended by a friend and it definitely lived up to expectations! Luckily, they were able to accommodate us as a walk-in for dinner, but supposedly reservations can be difficult to get. Every dish we had was absolutely incredible, as were the cocktails. Service was terrific and the staff offered excellent recommendations. A must when visiting London!

i-g87nNqOSbHwZ4jb2_XIQ.text: Layers of flavor and perfect technique describe the Indian cuisine. Exceptional, friendly welcoming service describe the staff. A gem in central London.

jG9Io0zU-EptYB_HiFPQ1w.text: So I have to say that I'm not an expert in Indian cuisine but I was very happy with my experience at Gymkhana.  I was nearby at Fortnum and Mason and popped in at 7:00 pm on a Tuesday night hoping I could get a table for one.  The restaurant was fully booked but there was a very small table near the bar that was offered to me.  Since I was craving Indian food, I was very happy to take it.  I ordered the lamb shank and it was delicious!  I wasn't very hungry, so I can't tell you about the appetizers or dessert.  Just had the lamb shank and some rice.  The lamb was very tender and tasty.

O7y6mLvr9HbYbR8aA2yc2g.text: Really great Indian food. Very inventive. I was expecting more of an high-end feel to the decor reflecting the prices it commands. It didn't help that some of the other customers were dressed like complete slobs.

bRoHN_UoywLSUNRIqkiprA.text: No idea how this place gets great reviews. However, I dined there when it first opened so it may have improved since then.On my visit, the food was late, cold and nothing to shout about.The dining area downstairs is dead and very depressing.The prices are outrageous considering what we got.In fact it was such a terrible experience that I have no desire to try the place again despite these latest reviews.

-xTn7LappmpSxHWXZ8XWWg.text: Delicious though pricey Indian cuisine in a casual atmosphere.  Skip the silly, over priced, cloying cocktails and go for wine list, which includes some reasonably priced possibilities.  Appetizer goat kheema was delicious, though needlessly accompanied by butter bread rolls.  Duck dosas were fresh and spicy.  Lamb chops were succulent, spicy and memorably delicious.  Dal Maharani was nothing special - it lacked a certain richness and depth of flavor.  Basmati rice was perfectly done - each grain was separate, aromatic and tasty.  Kulfi desert was just so-so.  The fresh spices provided layers of flavor made the goat, duck and lamb chops real stand-outs, overcoming the other mild disappointments. .  Note the Mayfair prices -- 160 pounds for two, with leftovers.

t6u5R87LZikfjjj9sXlgrQ.text: We had Mishal (sp?) as our waiter and the service could not have been better.  Not being very experienced with Indian food we "went with the waiter" and have absolutely no regrets.  Pablo the sommelier was also excellent...if you like great wine they have a limited but high quality list with moderate prices.  Can't wait to try it again next time I'm in London!

cA2hC7_anGjlOmDzipMbwg.text: Went to check out the hype and came away unimpressed and underwhelmed! Do Michelin food writers really know anything about real Indian food. The problem with Gymkhana is it's trying to beef too many things all at once hence not really delivering on any! We went for the lunch menu which at 25 quid in Mayfair for two courses is quite reasonable, they give you some papads / deep fried crisps with three chutneys, shrimp, mint and sweet, all three very average and the shrimp Chutney, was hoping will be similar to what you get in Goa, Kerala, but not to be  tasted like a Delhites attempt at bad South Indian! I had a dosa with duck, there only flavours I got from the duck was onions, similar to the shrimp Chutney. Similar look and taste from the Kheema and bheja ( and I was really looking forward to this given its my favourite spare part if the goat/ lamb), again onions aall over. The only thing that rescues them with a third star is the polite and courteous service!

B1SZelflUpI7Gk2w3isnug.text: Fine Indian dining at a very reasonable price (reasonable by London standards). This is the best Indian food I've had in London so far. I haven't been to some of the Michelin rated places here but Gymkhana is very high quality. You must order the kid goat keema. One of the best Indian dishes I've ever had. The cocktails are also wonderful which is not something you can say for most Indian restaurant's.

_8abka1mkf5LcJhCgcKrhw.text: I read the reviews and had high expectations for Gymkhana. The service was great as was their specially made (pale ale) beer.The butter chicken masala and nan were very good. I cannot say that about the coastal okra / side dish.   The prices were a little high and they still charge you for the basmati rice. Considering the prices, not sure if I would eat here again.

kgb6CJnzdEs8ikC_1UIisg.text: We walked here late from near the London Eye. We noticed most of the restaurants were closed nearby. We finally arrived close to 9:30 on a Sunday. Not sure why any sane family would bring there 6 and 10 year old children out to eat this late at night. We happened to be on EST from traveling here a couple days ago. After the more than 1.5 mile hike there with the kids, we were tired. The restaurant was packed. The hostess looked at us if we were crazy for walking in off the streets without a reservation. They were however VERY accommodating. After a short wait, they showed us to one of the best tables in the house located in the downstairs eating area. The entire staff quickly tended to our needs. Not exactly sure when I last experienced this incredible service. I am sure it was in Manhattan at a very expensive steak house in mid town. From the starters to the main course and excellent advice on scotches, we were completely amazed at how EVERYTHING came together from the moment we walked in the door to the helpful and VERY accommodating staff. I HIGHLY recommend this as the BEST Indian reaturant I have EVER had the opportunity to attend. As for recommendations from the staff. My favorite was the Lamb shank nihari aloof chokha and Lamb nali Barra. We had other amazing courses throughout and the kids loved the chicken butter masala. You won't be disappointed in your tasting journey or anything this staff can off you.
